results.title: Heart of Pearl
results.creator_credit: Andrew G Taylor, Jo-Anne McGowan and AFTRS
results.brief_description: An old soldier is trapped in time. Only a ticking watch separates his ritual from the enveloping jungle … ‘Heart of Pearl’ is based on stories of Japanese soldiers who remained in hiding in the jungle for decades after the end of World War II.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Andrew G Taylor, Jo-Anne McGowan and AFTRS

results.title: Heart of a stallion
results.creator_credit: Lew Landers, Carl Laemmle, Castle Films and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Excerpts from the 1935 feature film “Stormy” starring Noah Beery and Jean Rogers. Stormy (Noah Beery) goes in search of a lost horse - a victim of a train wreck. His search leads him into mountainous country where he encounters rustlers who plan to slaughter a whole herd of horses.

results.title: Heart and circulation
results.brief_description: Early use of microcinematography and electronic amplification to illustrate the workings of the heart’s action. Blood pressure and its relation to health is also dealt with.

results.title: Hear no evil. Babes on boards. Festivals. Neurodancer.
results.brief_description: This tape contains four short films by Australian directors. “Hear no evil” (produced by Fiona Hergstrom, directed by Kate Hampel): a young woman attempts to make her mark as a band manager in a particularly challenging environment, death metal. We watch as she overcomes barriers and prejudices and reaches towards her goal of managing the band full time. “Babes on boards” (produced by Deborah Rohde, directed by Adrian Holmes): follows the journey of three young women with a passion for surfing as they travel along the coast, surfing, arguing and enjoying themselves. One of them meets the challange of a competition - her ultimate goal. “Festivals” (produced by Caroline Waters, directed by Caroline Waters and Matthew Rooke): examines the culture of Australian music festivals. People who are involved in the festivals- participating and watching, are asked how they feel the festival contributes to society and youth culture. “Neurodancer” (produced by Simon Hay, directed by Chris Zwar): goes inside the Rave culture, a prominent youth culture within Australia. It probes the minds and attitudes of dancers, DJ’s, artists, musicians and outsiders.
results.title_for_label: Hear no evil. Babes on boards. Festivals. Neurodancer.

results.title: Hear better: healthy ears
results.brief_description: Opens with a summary of the pleasures that result from hearing well. The structure of the ear is shown in detail and the process of receiving air vibrations and transmitting them into sounds is explained. Concludes with general information on how to take care of the ears.

results.title: Healthy mother, healthy baby
results.brief_description: In this program the importance of proper nutrition and good eating habits during pregnancy are stressed. Also, the need for expectant mothers to make sound decisions regarding the use of alcohol, cigarettes, caffeine, and drugs, are explained. This film offers a valuable guide to pregnant women and teenagers.

results.title: Healthy lungs
results.creator_credit: David A. Smart and Coronet Instructional Films
results.brief_description: Shows the part of the breathing mechanism in contact with the air and demonstrates how the exchange of waste products for oxygen takes place. Explains how disease affects the lungs and recommends procedures to keep the lungs in a healthy condition.

results.title: Health: the inside story
results.brief_description: A common-sense approach to attaining and maintaining good health. Shows the role of muscular endurance, heart and lung endurance and nutrition in a healthy lifestyle. Indicates health hazards such as smoking and stress, and emphasises the need for relaxation. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Health: communicable diseases. - 2nd edition.
results.creator_credit: David Winter, Michael Wright and AIMS Instructional Media
results.brief_description: Using an animated clay germ to answer the question of how people get sick. The germ tells where germs live and how they are spread from person to person, and then shows how they can be prevented from spreading. Also presents cautionary measures to be taken when sick, along with cautions about taking medicine without grown-up supervision.
